Numerous factors played a role in the global spread of Chikungunya. Adaptive mutations in the Chikungunya genome enabled the East/Central/South African (ECSA) strain to be more easily transmitted by Ae. albopictus, contributing to the outbreak in La RÃ©union
10 and, subsequently, to outbreaks in south Asia and Italy. Globalization in trade and travel, meanwhile, have facilitated the geographic expansion of Ae. albopictus
11 and have increased the possibility that travellers infected with Chikungunya could come into contact with competent Aedes mosquito vectors
12, 13 .
